entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series: Traveling with My little Puppy and Finding Balance Beyond Tech :)
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

My name is Marla. I work as a Senior Data and AI Developer, and Today, Iâ€™d like to share a bit about my hobby as a part of the  SAP Community Hobbies series. ğŸ¤— Outside of work, one hobby has become very important to me over the last few years: traveling and exploring the world with my little puppy Carlo ğŸ˜ƒ ğŸ¶

It might sound simple, but it requires a lot of planning and creativity. How I organize my trips has also influenced how I think about systems and processes. Carlo is not just my travel companion. He is part of the journey and the reason many of these experiences exist in the first place.

How and when did I start this hobby?

I did not plan for this to become a hobby. It started naturally when I got Carlo five years ago and realized I did not want to stop traveling or leave him alone while Iâ€™m on vacation ğŸ¥¹. So naturally, instead of adapting my life to travel, I adapted travel to my life.ğŸ˜‰

Short trips, nature-focused destinations, dog-friendly cities and countries  ( I can totally recommend Croatia and Italy ), and flexible planning became the default. Over time, this turned into a routine and something I actively look forward to. Together, Carlo, my partner Niklas, and I have discovered many new places, from quiet nature spots to vibrant cities, always at a pace that works for all of us.

 

 

Me and Carlo on the way to attend a workshop in Belgrade- Serbia

 

visiting the stunning Externsteine in the Teutoburg Forest - Germany

 Having the best time in The Hague - the Netherlands

 

What do I love most about it?

The biggest value is presence. Traveling with a dog forces you to slow down. You walk more, you observe more, and you plan less around attractions and more around experiences. It clears my head in a way that very few things do, especially after intense project phases or long weeks in front of screens. It is also grounding. No notifications matter when you are on a forest path with a leash in your hand, or when Carlo decides that a certain spot is worth stopping for.

Challenges and how I deal with them

Traveling with a dog is not always easy. Not every hotel is dog-friendly. Public transport rules vary(For example, in Austria, Carlo has to wear a muzzle when using public transportation ğŸ˜… ). Planning takes more effort, especially across countries. I learned to research carefully, build buffers, and always have a backup plan.

A proud moment

My proudest moments are not big milestones. They are small wins. The first long train trip went smoothly. The first international trip without stress. Finding places where Carlo is relaxed, welcome, and curious rather than overwhelmed.

Those moments tell me that good preparation pays off.

Celebrating a friend's birthday in Zaragoza - Spain

 

 

 

Traviling to Berlin for TechEd 2025

 

 

flying to Mallorca -Spain

 

enjoying a ride in Texel- the Netherlands

Tools and resources for beginners

For anyone starting out, these are essential:

Dog-friendly accommodation platforms and search filters
Basic travel gear such as a good leash, a portable water bowl, and a transport-safe harness
Patience and realistic expectations. You do not need expensive equipment. You need planning and awareness.

 

Chilling at the Hotel in kÃ¼lingsborn-Germany

 

 

Flying to Spain again ğŸ˜„

 

 

 

Road trips with the car

 

Tips for getting started

Start small.ğŸ˜‰ Begin with day trips, then weekends, then longer journeys. Observe how your dog reacts and adjust. Do not aim for perfection. Aim for learning. The same applies to learning new SAP technologies. Iteration beats overplanning.

How I keep improving

I learn by doing. Each trip teaches me something new. Traveling with Carlo constantly challenges me to be more flexible and attentive. I also exchange tips with other dog owners and travelers. Reflection after each journey helps me improve the next one. Continuous improvement does not need formal training. It needs attention.

Common misconceptions

A common myth is that traveling with a dog is restrictive.In reality, it changes priorities, but it also opens new perspectives. You discover quieter places, nature-focused destinations, and a slower pace that many people are actually looking for.

Visiting Heidelberg

 

 

Carlo in Berlin ğŸ˜„

 

 

Chilling in Mallorca

Where to learn more

There are many blogs and communities focused on dog-friendly travel, especially in Europe and North America. Local communities are often more helpful than large platforms.

The connection to the SAP world

The connection is stronger than it seems.

Traveling with a dog is about systems thinking. You balance constraints, dependencies, timing, and user experience, where the user just happens to have four legs.

In SAP projects, especially in data and AI, we design architectures that must be robust, flexible, and humane. This hobby constantly reminds me that good systems serve real needs, not just technical elegance.It also helps me show up better at work. More focused, more patient, and more grounded.

What is next?

After discovering so many places together, our next big plan is to cross the Atlantic. Carlo and I are preparing for a longer journey, with New York and Toronto at the top of the list. It will be a new level of planning, learning, and adapting, and I am already looking forward to what we will discover next.

Thanks for reading. If you travel with your dog, or if you have found a hobby that helps you disconnect and think better, I would love to hear about it.

 

Hello from Karlsruhe

Coming up  next ğŸ¥

I am happy to pass the baton to  @HakanHasalman, who will introduce his writing hobby. ğŸ¤—

 

With Love,
Marla & Carlo

entry.title: Extending an SAP Sample Sankey Custom Widget in SAP Analytics Cloud to Deliver Top-N Hierarchical In
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) does not provide a native, built-in Sankey chart as part of its standard visualization catalog. As a result, Sankey-style visualizations in SAC are typically implemented using custom widgets.

In mid-2024, while working on an enterprise analytics engagement, I encountered a requirement to visualize:

  • Top N parent entities (for example, service providers)
  • And, for each parent, the Top M child entities independently ranked per parent (for example, services offered)

All of this needed to be displayed within a single Sankey visualization, enabling users to immediately understand concentration and distribution patterns without navigating multiple charts.

To address this requirement, I explored SACâ€™s Custom Widget framework and extended an existing SAP-provided sample Sankey custom widget into a production-ready solution.

I have intentionally included the development and deployment steps in detail so that consultants or developers who are completely new to Sankey custom widgets in SAP Analytics Cloud can deploy and validate the solution end-to-end by following this blog.

SAP Sample Sankey Custom Widget as the Starting Point

Since SAP Analytics Cloud does not include a native Sankey chart, I referred to a sample Sankey custom widget implementation shared by SAP through the SAP Community. This SAP-provided sample demonstrates how a Sankey diagram can be rendered using the SAC Custom Widget framework and served as a technical starting point for my work.

The SAP sample was very helpful as a technical reference, as it illustrated:

  • Custom widget structure and lifecycle
  • Binding SAC model data to a widget
  • Rendering a Sankey diagram using JavaScript

During mid-2024, while actively working on this requirement, I engaged in the comments section of that SAP Community blog (SAP Analytics Cloud: Custom Widget & Widget Add-Ons Samples Preview) under my SAP Community user@GovindaRaoBanothu45 , discussing feasibility and implementation boundaries.

While the sample clarified the basic rendering approach, it also highlighted functional gaps when applied to enterprise-scale analytical requirements.

Why the SAP Sample Sankey Widget Was Not Sufficient

The SAP-provided Sankey custom widget was intentionally designed as a generic sample. Its behavior was to render all nodes and all links returned by the bound dataset.

However, the sample widget did not support the enterprise analytical requirement I was addressing, specifically:

  • No Top-N filtering at the parent level
  • No independent ranking of child nodes per parent
  • No data trimming prior to Sankey rendering
  • Limited usability for large, real-world datasets

As a result, while the SAP sample demonstrated how to render a Sankey chart, it did not meet the analytical or usability needs of an enterprise dashboard.

This gap required extending and enhancing the SAP sample Sankey custom widget with additional, original logic to reshape the dataset before rendering.

High-Level Architecture of the Extended Sankey Widget

The Sankey rendering mechanism remains aligned with the SAP sample, while the data-transformation layer represents the core extension.

Development Environment and Prerequisites

Prerequisites

To get started, ensure that you have:

  • Access to SAP Analytics Cloud with Optimized Design Experience enabled
  • Node.js installed on your local machine
  • Visual Studio Code (VS Code) installed
  • Basic understanding of JavaScript and JSON

Development Environment Setup

Install Node.js

  1. Download Node.js from: https://nodejs.org
  2. Verify installation:
node -v
npm -v

Install Visual Studio Code

  1. Download VS Code from: https://code.visualstudio.com
  2. Use VS Code as the primary editor for developing and maintaining the custom widget files.

Set Up the Project Folder

  1. Create a project folder (for example, SankeySAPcode).
  2. Open the folder in Visual Studio Code.
  3. Create the following files:
  • main.js â€“ core widget logic and Sankey rendering
  • index.json â€“ metadata and resource configuration
  • hash256.js â€“ Node.js script for integrity key generation

Sankey Custom Widget â€“ Standard Project Structure

For the standard Sankey implementation, I created a dedicated project folder (for example, SankeySAPcode or any relevant project name). This folder contains all the supporting and required files needed to build and deploy the Sankey custom widget in SAP Analytics Cloud.

The project folder includes:

  • main.js
    The web component JavaScript file that contains the core widget logic and Sankey rendering code (mandatory).
  • index.json
    The metadata file that defines the custom widget, its properties, and resource references (mandatory).
  • sankeyChartStyling.js
    An optional styling component used to expose styling options in the widgetâ€™s styling panel (optional).
  • build/ folder
    Contains the helper script hash256.js, which is used to generate SHA-256 integrity keys for the JavaScript files.

Note: Styling files (Styling.js, sankeyChartStyling.js, or xxxxStyling.js) are optional and may not be required for all custom widgets.
However, the web component JavaScript file (main.js or equivalent) and the metadata file (index.json) are mandatory for every SAP Analytics Cloud custom widget. The build folder is included purely for maintainability and ease of understanding.
Technically, the hash256.js file can also be placed directly in the main project folder. Including it in a separate subfolder is optional and does not impact deployment, as long as the final ZIP file complies with SAP Analytics Cloudâ€™s upload requirements.

Creating Integrity Keys and Deploying the Code

SAP Analytics Cloud supports SHA-256 integrity validation to ensure uploaded JavaScript resources are not modified.

Generating Integrity Keys

  1. Open a Node.js command prompt
  2. Navigate to the folder containing hash256.js
  3. Execute the script

Example output:

  • main.js: sha256-6134FFLCQYpH7x8gx29H1xJyRbitpf/guj5UGKhJ25Q=
  • sankeyChartStyling.js:  sha256-AR0uDO+9h8nu9EyJotSinZ2APDWD5Ja2JmdFcZCH1Xo=

Note: If additional JavaScript resource files are included, their corresponding sha256- integrity keys must also be added to the index.json file under the resources section.

Similarly, the file names must be updated in hash256.js before generating integrity keys for those files.

Core Enhancement: Top-N Parent and Top-M Child Logic

The following snippets are representative excerpts from the working implementation.
Full scripts are intentionally not published, as this widget was delivered as part of an enterprise engagement.

In the widget, the SAC data binding is first normalized into an array (data) containing parent node, child node, and measure value fields.

Step 1: Aggregate Measure by Parent

const parentTotals = {};
data.forEach(row => {
  parentTotals[row.parentNode] =
    (parentTotals[row.parentNode] || 0) + Number(row.measureValue);
});

Step 2: Rank and Retain Top-N Parents

const topParents = Object.entries(parentTotals)
  .sort((a, b) => b[1] - a[1])
  .slice(0, TOP_N_PARENT_NODES)
  .map(entry => entry[0]);

Step 3: Rank and Retain Top-M Children per Parent

const filteredLinks = [];
topParents.forEach(parent => {
  const children = data
    .filter(row => row.parentNode === parent)
    .sort((a, b) => b.measureValue - a.measureValue)
    .slice(0, TOP_N_CHILD_NODES);

  children.forEach(child => {
    filteredLinks.push({
      source: parent,
      target: child.childNode,
      value:  child.measureValue
    });
  });
});

Step 4: Rebuild Nodes

const nodes = [...new Set(
  filteredLinks.flatMap(l => [l.source, l.target])
)].map(name => ({ name }));

Step 5: Render Sankey

sankey.nodes(nodes).links(filteredLinks).layout(32);

The rendering follows the SAP sample approach; the innovation lies in the data-transformation logic.

Once all required files and script updates are ready, letâ€™s deploy the custom widget into SAP Analytics Cloud.

Deploy the Custom Widget

  1. Create a ZIP File:
    • Include main.js, index.json, and optional styling files in a .zip file.
  2. Upload to SAP Analytics Cloud:
    • Navigate to the Custom Widgets section in SAC.
    • Upload the .json and .zip files.
  3. Test the Widget:
    • Add the custom widget to a story and configure data sources.

Select the JSON metadata file from your local system.

Next, select the resource file that is .zip file of main.js, index.json and styling.js or any other file related to this chart.

Now you can the widget in "Custom Widgets" section.

Observe the warning messages below with and/without integrity checks in the list of custom widgets

We have done custom widget deployment and will use the same in stories. Let's see how to access this in story 2.0.

 

From the builder panel, select your data model, set measure, set a hierarchical dimension and edit the default colors of the different depths from the Styling panel.

Below screenshot show the usage of the Styling.JS file.

In case the java script files get modified / tampered you get the below error while creating chart using custom widget in SAC story.

Validated Sankey Variants  - Let's validate 3 different scenarios

  • SAP sample Sankey (baseline):

                          

  • Top 1 parent + Top 5 child nodes:
    • This is the custom code and the main.js file is completely different than standard code with the key components are the below conditions below.

                        

                       Result of the above changes,

                    

  • Top 3 parents + Top 5 children:

                          

                        Result of the above changes,

                       

This incremental approach helped validate correctness before applying the logic to larger Top-N configurations.

Acknowledgment

I would like to thank @marouferchichi for actively engaging in the SAP Community blog comments and helping clarify the capabilities and boundaries of the sample Sankey custom widget.

The final implementation described here represents my independent extension and delivery of that sample to meet enterprise-level analytical requirements.

Conclusion

This blog demonstrates how a SAP sample Sankey custom widget can be extended into a production-grade Top-N hierarchical Sankey visualization using SAP Analytics Cloudâ€™s Custom Widget framework.

For similar enterprise scenarios, this approach provides a reusable and scalable pattern.

entry.title: My Journey into the SAP World: From Campus to BASIS Administrator
entry.content:
The Beginning

I graduated in 2025 and, through campus placements, landed an opportunity with a company called Mindsprint. At first, I was a little concerned about the role, but I decided to take the offer and explore SAP. I kept thinking, â€œMaybe God has a better plan for me.â€

I started as an intern for about six months. To be honest, during the internship, there werenâ€™t many tasks. Most of my time went into researching SAP BASIS concepts, but without access to a production system, learning was slow. Thankfully, with my teamâ€™s support, I converted to a full-time roleâ€”and thatâ€™s when the real journey began.

Where I Am Today

Itâ€™s been about four months since I officially entered the SAP field, and my role is BASIS Administrator. So far, Iâ€™ve worked on:

  • Transport Requests (TR) Movements
  • Kernel Upgrades
  • HDB Client Upgrade
  • Exposure to ChaRM, CALM, and BTP Administration

Iâ€™ve been lucky to have a great team and plenty of opportunities to learn. But recently, Iâ€™ve started noticing repetitive tasks, and that got me thinking: Whatâ€™s next?

SAP: An Ocean of Opportunities

SAP feels like an oceanâ€”so many things to explore! I want to grow in this field, learn whatâ€™s trending, and stay ahead. My seniors say Iâ€™ve had good exposure already, but Iâ€™m hungry for more.

For context, I have a B.Tech in CSE, so coding isnâ€™t new to me. Recently, I explored SAP BTP with Terraform, which was exciting. But now, Iâ€™m wondering:
âœ… What should I learn next?
âœ… Whatâ€™s the future of SAP?
âœ… Which skills will help me stand out in the market?

Your Guidance Matters

If youâ€™re experienced in SAP or have insights into the latest trends, Iâ€™d love your suggestions. Should I dive deeper into BTP, Cloud, Automation, or something else?

SAP is vast, and I want to make sure Iâ€™m swimming in the right direction. Your advice could help shape my next steps!

 

Thanks for reading my story! If youâ€™ve been on a similar journey or have tips for someone starting out, please share. Letâ€™s learn and grow together!

entry.title: Introduction
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community!

I am excited to start my journey in the SAP Community. My goal is to learn how to get started, explore tips for meaningful participation, and connect with experts and fellow learners. The SAP Community Welcome Corner has been a great guide, helping me make the most of this collaborative space. Through this blog, I will share my experiences, insights, and discoveries as I navigate the community and grow my SAP skills.

I look forward to learning, sharing, growing, and actively participating in the SAP Community.

Best Regards,

Yugandhar
